sanskrit:
प्रणम्य शिरसा विष्णुं त्रैलोक्याधिपतिं प्रभुम् ।
नानाशास्त्रोद्धृतं वक्ष्ये नीतिśास्त्रमनुत्तमम् ॥
translation: Bowing my head to Lord Vishnu, the ruler of the three worlds, I recite the supreme rules of conduct drawn from various scriptures.

sanskrit:
त्यजेदेकं कुलस्यार्थे ग्रामस्यार्थे कुलं त्यजेत् ।
ग्रामं जनपदस्यार्थे आत्मार्थे पृथिवीं त्यजेत् ॥
translation: One should sacrifice an individual for the sake of the family, the family for the sake of the village, the village for the sake of the country, and even the entire earth for the sake of the soul.

sanskrit:
सत्यं ब्रूयात् प्रियं ब्रूयात् न ब्रूयात् सत्यमप्रियम् ।
प्रियं च नानृतं ब्रूयात् एष धर्मः सनातनः ॥
translation: Speak the truth, speak it pleasantly, and do not speak unpleasant truths. Never speak lies, even if they are pleasing — this is the eternal dharma.

sanskrit:
न चोरराज्यं न च दुष्टसेवा न चान्नदाता व्यसनेषु मित्रम् ।
न चाल्पविद्येः न च वृद्धसेवा चाणक्यं त्यजति बुद्धिमन्तः ॥
translation: The wise abandon the rule of thieves, evil company, friends who abandon in danger, an unlearned guide, and the service of the old or ineffective.

sanskrit:
को हि धर्मार्थयुक्तानां त्यागिनां साधुसङ्गिनाम् ।
कः समयमनुप्राप्य न सिध्यति करोत्यपि ॥
translation: Who does not succeed, if at the right time, one practices righteousness, detachment, and good association?

sanskrit:
संपत्तौ च विपत्तौ च महतां व्यवहारिता ।
उत्सवे व्यसने चैव ज्ञायन्ते सत्पुरुषाः ॥
translation: In prosperity and adversity, the behavior of great people is seen. True character is revealed during celebrations and crises.

sanskrit:
माता शत्रुः पिता वैरी येन बालो न पाठितः ।
न शोभते सभा मध्ये हंसमध्ये बको यथा ॥
translation: That child whose parents do not educate him becomes their enemy. He is like a crane among swans in an assembly.

sanskrit:
येषां न विद्या न तपो न दानं ज्ञानं न शीलं न गुणो न धर्मः ।
ते मर्त्यलोके भुवि भारभूता मनुष्यरूपेण मृगाः चरन्ति ॥
translation: Those who have neither learning nor austerity, nor charity, nor knowledge, nor character, nor virtue, nor dharma — they are a burden to the earth, animals in human form.

sanskrit:
एकेनapi सुपुत्रेण विद्यायुक्तेन संस्कृतः ।
वशं वर्ति जगत्सर्वं यत्र पूज्यं धनं कुलम् ॥
translation: A single virtuous and learned son brings fame and respect to the entire family. He is more valuable than wealth or lineage.

sanskrit:
न चौरहार्यं न च राजहार्यं न भ्रातृभाज्यं न च भारकारी ।
व्यये कृते वर्धते नित्यं विद्याधनं सर्वधनप्रधानम् ॥
translation: Knowledge is the greatest wealth: it cannot be stolen by thieves, seized by kings, divided among brothers, or burdensome to carry. It increases when shared.

sanskrit:
सुपुत्रो जायते तस्य कुले भार्या पतिव्रता ।
संपन्नः स तु नारीणां यत्र भग्नं कुलं सदा ॥
translation: He is truly blessed who has a virtuous wife and a noble son, for in such a home, the family is always elevated.

sanskrit:
दुर्जनः परिहर्तव्यो विद्ययाऽलंकृतोऽपि सन् ।
मणिना भूषितः सर्पः किमसौ न भयंकरः ॥
translation: Even if an evil person is adorned with learning, he should be avoided. Is a serpent less dangerous because it is jeweled?

sanskrit:
शक्यं जलप्लवेनैव दुस्तरं सागरं यथा ।
न तु विद्याविहीनस्य न तरणं न गमनं ॥
translation: One may cross a great ocean by a raft, but the ignorant cannot cross even a small stream of life without knowledge.

sanskrit:
गुणा यदि भवन्त्येव दोषाः किं बहु भाषितम् ।
गन्धेन विवरं यान्ति फलान्यपि च काकतः ॥
translation: When one possesses virtues, flaws become insignificant. Even crows seek fruits through fragrance.

sanskrit:
निन्दन्तु नीतिनिपुणा यदि वा स्तुवन्तु लक्ष्मीः समाविशतु गच्छतु वा यथेष्टम् ।
अद्यैव वा मरणमस्तु युगान्तरे वा न्यायात्पथः प्रविचलन्ति पदं न धीराः ॥
translation: Let critics criticize or praise, let wealth come or go, let death come today or after ages — the wise never stray from the path of righteousness.
